truth.title: Opening – Set the Frame Fast
points: Smile before you speak; they can hear it.
Say their name clearly and confidently.
Sound like you expected them to pick up — no apology energy.

values.title: Values – Respect Their Time
points: You’re calling because they requested info.
Be direct, clear, and calm from the first second.

mindset.title: Mindset – You’re the Selector
points: You’re not begging for their time; you’re screening for a good fit.
Think: “I’m here to see if this is a win–win.”

habits.title: Habits – Consistent Openings
points: Use the same opener every time until it’s automatic.
Track dials → conversations → interviews.

skillset.title: Skillset – First Impressions
points: Clear pacing, no filler words.
Match their energy but always lead with certainty.

truth.title: Compliance – Don’t Rush It
points: Deliver this calm and matter-of-fact, like it’s no big deal.
Pause and wait for a clear 'yes' before moving on.
If they hesitate, reassure them it’s standard.

values.title: Values – Transparency
points: You’re modeling honesty and professionalism from the jump.
Never skip the recording line, even if you’re in a hurry.

mindset.title: Mindset – Pros Like Structure
points: Serious people appreciate clear, compliant processes.
Assume they’ll say yes unless they explicitly object.

habits.title: Habits – Same Wording Every Time
points: Use the same sentence each call to reduce mental load.
Let yourself get bored of it — that means it’s automatic.

skillset.title: Skillset – Handling Recording Objections
points: Acknowledge concern, explain the why, offer a simple choice.

truth.title: Frame – Why You’re Asking Questions
points: Set expectation that this is an interview, not a sales pitch.
Calms them down so discovery doesn’t feel random.

values.title: Values – Honesty About Fit
points: You’re not trying to shove them into a role that doesn’t fit.
You’re willing to tell them no if it’s not right.

mindset.title: Mindset – You’re Evaluating
points: You’re here to see if they qualify, not to win them over.
The less attached you are, the better the call goes.

habits.title: Habits – Use This Same Frame
points: Don’t improvise here; use the same framing every call.
This becomes your mental “start of interview” switch.

skillset.title: Skillset – Simple Language
points: Keep the explanation short and conversational.
End with a light 'fair enough?' to invite buy-in.

truth.title: Work & Money – Big Picture
points: You’re getting context: what they do now and why they’re looking.
Listen more than you talk; save coaching for later.

values.title: Values – Curiosity First
points: Don’t judge their current situation.
Your job is to understand, not impress.

mindset.title: Mindset – Detective Mode
points: Be genuinely curious about how they think and operate.
Assume there’s more under the surface — ask follow-ups.

habits.title: Habits – Always Start Here
points: First bucket is always work & money; don’t skip it.
Take quick notes as they talk.

skillset.title: Skillset – Open Questions
points: Use questions that can’t be answered with just yes/no.
Follow up with 'Tell me more about that.'

truth.title: Frame – Three Paths Overview
points: You’re lowering pressure by giving them all possible outcomes upfront.
This makes the call feel fair and transparent instead of like a pitch.

values.title: Values – No Hidden Agenda
points: You’re clear that the goal is to see if there’s a fit, not to force a yes.
People relax when they know you’re willing to tell them no.

mindset.title: Mindset – Calm Authority
points: You’re in control of the process, not rushing to a close.
Think: 'I’m here to help them make the right decision, even if it’s no.'

habits.title: Habits – Same Frame Every Time
points: Deliver the same three-path explanation on every call.
This consistency makes you smoother and frees up mental bandwidth.

skillset.title: Skillset – Framing Without Jargon
points: Use simple, conversational language.
Pause briefly after explaining the three paths so it lands.

truth.title: Path 1 – Perfect Fit
points: You’re future-pacing the best-case scenario: a second, deeper interview.
Serious people lean in when they hear there’s a higher bar to clear.

values.title: Values – Merit-Based Opportunities
points: Only people who truly fit move forward.
You’re signaling that you don’t just take anyone with a credit card.

mindset.title: Mindset – Invite, Don’t Chase
points: You’re describing an opportunity they might earn, not something you’re begging them to take.
Think: 'They’re applying to work with Brad, not the other way around.'

habits.title: Habits – Light but Serious Tone
points: Keep your tone positive and confident, not hyped or desperate.
Smile when mentioning the best-case path; they’ll feel it.

skillset.title: Skillset – Future Pacing
points: Clearly describe what the next step looks like (2nd interview, deeper dive, comp talk).
Don’t over-explain here; details come later.

truth.title: Path 2 – Not a Fit
points: You normalize 'no' as a possible outcome right up front.
This builds trust because it proves you’re not afraid to disqualify.

values.title: Values – Respect
points: Even if they’re not a fit, you leave them with dignity.
You’re modeling how pros exit conversations gracefully.

mindset.title: Mindset – Abundance
points: There are more applicants than spots; you don’t need to force bad fits.
Think: 'A clean no is better than a messy maybe.'

habits.title: Habits – Stay Neutral
points: Don’t sound negative when you mention 'not a fit.'
Deliver it calmly so they don’t feel judged or defensive.

skillset.title: Skillset – De-Pressurizing
points: By explaining this path early, you reduce fear of being sold.
That makes discovery smoother and more honest.

truth.title: Path 3 – Needs Training
points: You plant the idea that training is a valid, respectable option.
This paves the way for the Real Training offer later in the call.

values.title: Values – Development
points: You position growth as normal, not as something to be ashamed of.
You’re telling them 'needing coaching' is okay.

mindset.title: Mindset – Coach, Not Critic
points: You’re evaluating their potential, not picking them apart.
Think: 'With the right reps, they could become a killer closer.'

habits.title: Habits – Mention Training Every Time
points: Don’t skip this third path even if you suspect they’re a rockstar.
You want your brain used to all three outcomes.

skillset.title: Skillset – Seeding
points: This is where you first seed the concept of structured training.
Keep it neutral; don’t 'sell' training yet.

truth.title: Frame Close – 'Fair Enough?'
points: You’re getting micro-agreement that they’re onboard with the process.
This makes it easier to guide them later.

values.title: Values – Collaboration
points: You invite them to participate in the structure instead of forcing it.
People follow better when they’ve said yes to the ground rules.

mindset.title: Mindset – Calm Confidence
points: Say 'fair enough?' like you already know the answer is yes.
If they hesitate, you can slow down and re-explain the paths.

habits.title: Habits – Pause and Listen
points: Actually wait for their response; don’t just roll into discovery.
This pause also lets you reset your own focus.

skillset.title: Skillset – Check-Ins
points: Use quick check-ins like this throughout the call to keep them with you.
It’s easier to course-correct early than at the close.

truth.title: Sales & PD – Are They a Pro or a Fan?
points: You’re finding out whether they’ve actually sold or just like the idea of sales.
Personal development history shows how serious they are about growth.

values.title: Values – Ownership
points: People who invest in themselves tend to take responsibility for outcomes.
You’re filtering for those who already take growth seriously.

mindset.title: Mindset – Respect the Grind
points: Don’t judge low experience; judge effort and willingness to learn.
Look for people who have at least tried to bet on themselves.

habits.title: Habits – Ask for Specifics
points: Always follow up with 'What did you actually sell?' and 'How did you do?'
Ask what they liked or didn’t like about previous roles.

skillset.title: Skillset – Qualification
points: You’re qualifying their starting point so you can recommend the right path.
Strong answers here can override weaker areas in other buckets.

truth.title: Remote Setup – Can They Actually Work?
points: You’re checking that they have the basics: phone, computer, internet, quiet space.
If they can’t create a good environment, performance will suffer.

values.title: Values – Professionalism
points: Working from home still requires a professional setup.
You’re protecting the brand and the prospect experience.

mindset.title: Mindset – Self-Directed
points: You’re looking for people who can execute without being babysat.
Ask yourself: 'Would I trust this person to work alone?'

habits.title: Habits – Confirm Details
points: Always confirm device, internet, and schedule.
Don’t assume they’re ready just because they say 'remote is fine.'

skillset.title: Skillset – Expectation Setting
points: Remind them this is a performance role, not a 'work when you feel like it' job.
Lightly test their seriousness about hours and availability.

truth.title: Why & Vision – What’s Really Driving Them
points: You want the emotional 'why' behind their interest.
Surface-level answers usually mean low staying power.

values.title: Values – Alignment
points: You’re checking whether their goals align with commission-based sales.
Someone who only wants 'stability' may not love this environment.

mindset.title: Mindset – Long-Term Thinking
points: You want people who can think 12–18 months ahead, not just to Friday.
Listen for ownership language vs victim language.

habits.title: Habits – Let Them Talk
points: Ask the question and then shut up.
If they give a short answer, follow with 'Why is that important to you?'

skillset.title: Skillset – Emotional Discovery
points: This is about emotion, not data.
You’re looking for a lever you can reference later when they hesitate.

truth.title: Runway – Can They Survive the Ramp-Up?
points: You’re making sure they won’t panic if money doesn’t come in immediately.
Honest answers here prevent future blow-ups.

values.title: Values – Radical Honesty
points: You want them to tell the truth about their situation.
You’d rather say 'not now' than put them in a worse spot.

mindset.title: Mindset – Responsibility
points: They must own their finances and risk tolerance.
This isn’t about judging them; it’s about protecting them.

habits.title: Habits – Ask It Every Time
points: Never skip the runway question, even if they sound strong.
This keeps you from pushing people into situations they can’t handle.

skillset.title: Skillset – Tough Conversations
points: Ask with empathy but directness.
If they’re tight on runway, you may steer them toward more training first.

truth.title: Training Bridge – Shoot Them Straight
points: You’re being honest that they’re not ready to crush it on day one.
You frame this as a performance issue, not a character flaw.

values.title: Values – Protecting the Brand & Leads
points: Leads are expensive; you respect the pipeline.
You’re not willing to throw a rookie into live fire without support.

mindset.title: Mindset – Coach, Not Judge
points: Think: 'You can absolutely get there; you just need reps and direction.'
Deliver the feedback with belief, not criticism.

habits.title: Habits – Always Offer a Path
points: Never just say 'you’re not ready' without giving a way forward.
Training is the path for people with potential.

skillset.title: Skillset – Framing Gaps as Fixable
points: Make it clear that their weaknesses are trainable skills.
This keeps them encouraged instead of deflated.

truth.title: Deposit Setup – Why There’s a Cost
points: You’re explaining that the program is real, structured, and not cheap to run.
You use the deposit to separate serious people from dabblers.

values.title: Values – Commitment
points: You only want people who are willing to back themselves.
A little skin in the game means they’ll show up differently.

mindset.title: Mindset – Bet on Yourself
points: You want them thinking of the deposit as a commitment to their future self.
People who won’t bet on themselves rarely do the work.

habits.title: Habits – Say It Calmly
points: Deliver the deposit explanation like it’s standard (because it is).
Don’t flinch or oversell; just state it plainly.

skillset.title: Skillset – Pre-Handling Money Objections
points: By explaining the 'why' behind the deposit, you weaken objections later.
This is framing, not pressure.

truth.title: Deposit – Fully Refundable as Long as You Don’t Quit
points: This line removes most of the risk in their mind.
It also reinforces that quitting is the only way they truly lose.

values.title: Values – Fairness
points: You’re telling them 'If you show up and do the work, you won’t lose your deposit.'
This is about mutual commitment, not trapping them.

mindset.title: Mindset – Shared Risk
points: You’re basically saying, 'We’ll invest in you if you invest in you.'
It’s a partnership, not a one-sided deal.

habits.title: Habits – Emphasize 'Don’t Quit'
points: Put a tiny bit of weight on 'as long as you don’t quit.'
You’re setting the expectation that they’ll finish what they start.

skillset.title: Skillset – Risk Reversal
points: Use this to calm fear, then move straight into logistics.
Don’t linger so long that they overthink it.

truth.title: Real Training – Why It Exists
points: You’re positioning this as the solution to the exact gaps you just uncovered.
This isn’t a random course; it’s a bridge between where they are and the role they want.

values.title: Values – Results Over Hype
points: You’re selling the outcome (skills, income, confidence), not just access to content.
You want them in the program only if they plan to use it.

mindset.title: Mindset – Investment, Not Expense
points: You want them thinking 'what will this return?' not just 'what does this cost?'
People who win long-term see training as fuel, not a bill.

habits.title: Habits – Connect Back to Discovery
points: When you present Real Training, tie it back to the problems they told you they have.
The more specific you are, the less generic it feels.

skillset.title: Skillset – Framing Training With Belief
points: Deliver this part with calm certainty, not hype.
You’re inviting them into something you’d be proud to put your name on.

truth.title: 2nd Interview – Commission Reality Check
points: You’re making sure they understand this isn’t a salary job.
Better to lose them now than have them freak out later.

values.title: Values – Radical Clarity
points: You don’t hide the commission-only part behind fine print.
You want people who are excited by performance pay, not surprised by it.

mindset.title: Mindset – Filter, Don’t Convince
points: You’re not trying to talk them into commission-only.
If they truly hate it, they probably won’t last anyway.

habits.title: Habits – Ask and Pause
points: Ask if they’re good with commission-only, then shut up and listen.
Their tone matters more than the exact words.

skillset.title: Skillset – Framing Upside and Responsibility
points: You can briefly remind them there’s no ceiling on earnings.
But don’t oversell; this is about making sure they understand the deal.

truth.title: Not a Fit – Clean Exit
points: You’re protecting both them and the brand by being honest.
A respectful no can still leave the door open for later.

values.title: Values – Integrity Over Commission
points: You’d rather lose a potential sale than put the wrong person in the wrong seat.
This is how you build a long-term reputation.

mindset.title: Mindset – Abundance & Standards
points: You’re not desperate; you’re selective.
Saying no to the wrong people makes space for the right ones.

habits.title: Habits – Thank Them
points: Always thank them for their time and candor.
Log clear notes so they aren’t accidentally chased later.

skillset.title: Skillset – Graceful Close
points: Deliver the no calmly and kindly, without over-explaining.
Offer a soft door like 'If things change, you’re welcome to reapply.'
